ol.li:
What is @product.name@?
WSO2 Business Process Server (BPS) is an easy-to-use Open Source Business Process Server that executes business processes written following WS-BPEL standard. It serves as the business process management and hosting environment for your SOA. .

li.h3: What is the Open Source License of @product.name@?
li.p: It is released under Apache Software License Version 2.0.

li.h3: How do I get @product.name@?
li.p: @product.name@ is distributed completely free and all the distribution packs can be downloaded from the WSO2 Oxygen Tank. @product.name@ can be downloaded as a binary distribution or a source distribution and if required one can even checkout the complete source code from the WSO2 SVN repository.

li.h3: Is their commercial support available for @product.name@?
li.p: We are committed to ensuring that your enterprise middleware deployment is completely supported from evaluation to production. Our unique approach ensures that all support leverages our open development methodology and is provided by the very same engineers who build the technology. For more details and to take advantage of this unique opportunity please visit WSO2 Support.

li.h3: Can I get involved with the BPS development activities?
li.p: Not only you are allowed, but it is encouraged. You can start by subscribing to carbon-dev@wso2.org and architecture@wso2.org mailing lists. Feel free to provide ideas, feed back and help us make our code better. You can also report bugs on our issue tracker and you can even submit patches. Visit WSO2 Oxygen Tank for more information about our mailig lists.

li.h3: What is the recommended WS-BPEL designer tool to develop BPEL processes?
li.p: WSO2 carbon-studio is recommended.

li.h3: Is it possible to debug a BPEL process?
li.p: Yes. You can debug a BPEL process using the Event Table in the Instance View of Management Console or using the Message Tracer.

li.h3: How can I install BPEL feature to any of the carbon based servers?
li.p: Get the BPEL feature from the P2 repository and install it using the Carbon feature configuration functionality.

li.h3: Why do we need a Deployment Descriptor?
li.p: The deploy.xml file acts as the deployment descriptor for a BPEL package. It maps configuration information such as partner links, WSDL service, port, etc for processes in a BPEL archive.

li.h3: What are the BPEL Process Configurations?
li.p: The BPEL Process Configurations represents activities carried out within a business process written using WS-BPEL. The Basic Activities includes; Invoke, Receive, Reply, Assign, Compensate, CompensateScope, Exit, Throw, Empty, Rethrow, Wait. The Structured Activities includes; Flow, ForEach, If, Pick, RepeatUntil, Scope, Sequence, While.

li.h3: How can I get a message trace for a particular BPEL invocation?
li.p: Add log4j.logger.org.wso2.carbon.bpel.messagetrace=TRACE to log4j.properties file (located at @product.name@-@product.version@/repository/conf/log4j.properties) and set the Carbon log file threshold to trace. i.e. log4j.appender.CARBON_LOGFILE.threshold=TRACE Now re-start the BPS server and send a single request to the BPEL process and find the log file: BPS_HOME/repository/logs/wso2carbon.log

li.h3: How can I secure a BPEL process?
li.p: Apply either "Basic Security Scenarios" or "Advanced Security Scenarios" based on your preference.

li.h3: Can I execute a BPEL process inside a proxy service created using WSO2 ESB?
li.p: Yes. @product.name@ exposes business processes written in BPEL as web services. These services can be executed by a proxy service hosted in WSO2 Enterprise Service Bus (ESB) just like any other web service.

li.h3: Can I send email-notifications using @product.name@?
li.p: Yes. Create a proxy service which sends out emails using WSO2 ESB and call this proxy service within the BPEL process using "invoke" activity

li.h3: How can I start multiple carbon server instances?
li.p: Change the offSet value in the carbon.xml in each instance to different values.

li.h3: Can @product.name@ be deployed in clustered or other configurations intended to provide fault tolerance and increased performance?
li.p: Yes @product.name@ supports clustering.

li.h3: How does WS-BPEL handle human tasks?
li.p: WS-BPEL 2.0 does not address human interactions directly. The BPEL4People is an extension to WS-BPEL 2.0 and is used to model human interactions within a BPEL process through the use of an extension activity.

body.h2: Core (Questions related to the Carbon core and underlying framework)

li.h3: What are the technologies used underneath @product.name@?
What are the minimum requirements to run @product.name@?

ul.li: The extracted binary distribution of @product.name@ takes up about 150 MB of disk space

li.h3: How do I deploy a third party library into the BPS?
li.p: You can deploy any third party jar into the repository/components/lib directory. You also need to restart the server for the newly deployed jars to be picked up by the server runtime. @product.name@ will convert any jar files copied into the above location into OSGi bundles. These OSGi bundles are placed in the repository/components/dropins directory.

li.h3: Can I extend the management console UI to add custom UIs ?
li.p: Yes, you can extend the management console easily by writing a custom UI component.

li.h3: Can I use an external user store to manage and authenticate @product.name@ users?
li.p: Yes you can. You can connect @product.name@ with any external user store implementation. The user store could be LDAP based, JDBC based or a custom developed user store. Please refer user core documentation for more details.

li.h3: I don't want some of the features that come with @product.name@. Can I get rid of them?
li.p: Yes you can. Login to the BPS management console and browse to the Feature Manager. Open the 'Installed Features' tab. From here you can uninstall any unwanted features.

li.h3: Can I add support for other language for the management console ?
li.p: Yes, @product.name@ comes with a UI framework which supports i18n (internationalization) which lets you to use a language of your choice for the management console.

li.h3: What are the implications of hot deployment/hot update in a production environment?
li.p: Hot deployment/hot update may take the system to inconsistent states if the updates are not properly coordinated. Therefore it is recommended to turn hot deployment and hot update off for production deployments.

li.h3: I already have a WSO2 Governance Registry instance that contains my organization's SOA metadata. Can I get @product.name@ to use that registry instance as the metadata store?
li.p: @product.name@ integrates with WSO2 Governance Registry out of the box. Refer the administrator guide for the necessary steps involved in remote registry configuration.

li.h3: What are the versions of Java supported by the BPS?
li.p: It is tested on JDK 1.6. Sun JDK and IBM JDK are supported.

li.h3: What are the minimum artifacts required to deploy WSO2?
li.p: When deploying you can remove, $BPS_HOME/samples and $BPS_HOME/repository/samples from the standard distribution.

li.h3: How can I disable the management console ?
li.p: You can uninstall all the UI components using the feature manager which will disable the management console.

li.h3: Does @product.name@ supports application server deployments?
li.p: It has been tested on the following app servers. JBoss, Weblogic, Websphere and Tomcat.

li.h3: What are the recommended hardware and software configurations for a typical @product.name@ deployment?

ul.li: The extracted binary distribution of @product.name@ takes up about 130 MB of disk space (@product.name@ will require more disk space at runtime to keep temporary files, server logs etc)

li.h3: What is the database management system used in @product.name@?
li.p: @product.name@ ships with an embedded H2 database. However any database management system can be plugged into the BPS via JDBC. Database for BPEL engine persistence storage can be configured via datasources.properties file in repository/conf directory. Registry and user management related database configurations are available in repository/conf/registry.xml and repository/conf/user-mgt.xml files. @product.name@ has been tested with MySQL, Oracle, MSSQL and PostgreSQL databases.

li.h3: How can I change the memory allocation for the @product.name@?
li.p: The memory allocation setting are in the wso2server.sh. The user can change the memory allocation settings by changing the following configuration.
-Xms256m -Xmx512m -XX:MaxPermSize=128m
